results.title: The Sky is Bluer
results.creator_credit: Nadine Samaha, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Nadine Samaha left Lebanon in 1988 to escape the war but found a renewed love for her country through her daughter.

results.title: Loving Lebanon and Australia
results.creator_credit: Sam Haddad, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: When Lebanese immigrant Sam Haddad migrated to Australia he encountered ignorance and racism but via a well timed punch, he learned the value of mateship and tolerance and began to love his adopted country.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Sam Haddad, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: The Youth who wanted to shiver
results.creator_credit: Sam Weiss, C B Wismar, Nick Bosustow, Acton Films and Bosustow Entertainment

video_links.name: The Youth who wanted to shiver

results.brief_description: An animated adaptation of the classic fairy tale by the Brothers Grimm, about Jack who knows no fear and wants to be able to shiver. All help fails until his bride pours a bucket of tiny fish over him.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Sam Weiss, C B Wismar, Nick Bosustow, Acton Films and Bosustow Entertainment

results.title: Fisherman & his wife: a Grimm's fairy tale
results.creator_credit: Sam Weiss, C B Wismar, Nick Bosustow, Bosustow Entertainment and Churchill Films

video_links.name: Fisherman & his wife: a Grimm's fairy tale

results.brief_description: A Grimm’s fairy tale about a humble fisherman who frees a prince from a spell. The fisherman’s wife siezes the opportunity to have all her wishes granted but ends up where she started, thus learning a bitter lesson.
results.title_for_label: Fisherman & his wife: a Grimm’s fairy tale
results.creator_credit_for_label: Sam Weiss, C B Wismar, Nick Bosustow, Bosustow Entertainment and Churchill Films

results.title: Sydney Harbour Bridge. Bondi. Sydney Bush. Cars
results.brief_description: A compilation of four experimental films made by filmmaker, Paul Winkler, between 1977 - 1980: “Sydney Harbour Bridge”, “Bondi”, “Sydney Bush” and “Cars”.

results.title: Is it always right to be right?
results.creator_credit: Lee Mishkin, Nick Bosustow and Stephen Bosustow Productions

video_links.name: Is it always right to be right?

results.brief_description: This fast moving parable, designed to provoke discussion without alienating any group, highlights the centres of divisiveness in our society, the generation gap, poverty, war and race. It tells of a land “where men were always right”. This animated film is a winner of many awards including an Academy Award. Narrated by Orson Welles.
results.title_for_label: Is it always right to be right?
results.creator_credit_for_label: Lee Mishkin, Nick Bosustow and Stephen Bosustow Productions

results.title: The Apple
results.creator_credit: Samira Makhmalbaf, Iraj Sarbaz, Hubert Bals Fund, Makhmalbaf Productions and MK2 Productions
results.brief_description: Two girls locked in the home for eleven years finally get a chance to go out and play. Like many recent films from Iran, this one has a simple plot line, light humour, a humanitarian streak, and resonance due to its use of metaphor and rather complex themes. The film starts with concerned neighbours signing a petition for social workers to investigate a home where their blind mother and out-of-work father have locked up two girls for eleven years. Social workers “rescue” the (now severely intellectually and socially stunted) girls then give them back to their parents. What follows is an initiation period in which a social worker and the father have a seriocomic encounter whereby he gets a kind of comeuppance and the girls venture into the neighbourhood and begin to make friends despite their lack of social skills. What’s most harrowing about the film is that it’s based on a real life event and the principal characters play themselves, and it’s directed by an 18 year-old Iranian woman. Samira Makhmalbaf was able to shoot this film with film stock left over from her father’s (Mohsen Makhmalbaf) film “Sokhout” (1998). In Farsi with English subtitles. Cast includes Ghorban Ali Naderi, Azizeh Mohamadi, Massoumeh Naderi, Zahra Naderi and Zahra Saghrisaz.
